titleStmt.title: On Designing a Novel Self-Triggered Sampling Scheme for Networked Control Systems with Data Losses and Communication Delays

affiliation.orgName: School of Mechatronic Engineering and Automation
Shanghai Key Laboratory of Power Station Automation Technology
School of Mechatronic Engineering and Automation
Shanghai Key Laboratory of Power Station Automation Technology

analytic.title: On Designing a Novel Self-Triggered Sampling Scheme for Networked Control Systems with Data Losses and Communication Delays

biblStruct.note: received January 22, 2015; revised August 13, 2015 and October 24, 2015; accepted November 08, 2015.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: A self-triggered sampling scheme is proposed for a networked control system with consideration of data losses and communication delays. By making use of this scheme, the next sampling instant does not depend on on-line estimation of an event-triggered condition and the successive measurement of the state, and can be dynamically determined with respect to the transmitted packet, the desired control performance, and the allowable number of consecutive data losses and communication delays. Consequently, the sampling interval can be adaptively adjusted. Therefore, the communication burden can be greatly reduced and the energy efficiency can be much improved while preserving the desired H∞ performance. An inverted pendulum and a one-area power system controlled over a wireless sensor network are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed self-triggered sampling scheme.

the desired control performance at the same time has received much attention [10], [11], [12], [13], [14]. Furthermore, there are some reports on practical applications of NCSs [3], [7]. For example, an original two-layer structure is proposed to solve the set points compensation problem for a rougher flotation process under network-based environment [15]. To tackle multi-rate networked industrial process control problem, a stirred tank reactor is used to illustrate the effectiveness of proposed double-layer architecture [16].

In an NCS, the driven manner of the system components is one of key concerns in the modelling, analysis and synthesis. In the existing literature, a time-triggered sampling scheme is widely adopted [17], [18]. Generally speaking, executing the sampling in a time-triggered style is convenient for the analysis and design of NCSs, but it always leads to a conservative design. Since this sampling scheme uses the communication resources regardless of the behavior of the system and/or the current network load. Therefore, it is significant to design an appropriate communication/sampling scheme to ensure the desired performance while utilizing the less network bandwidth. Recently, a number of research results focus on event-triggered sampling schemes [10], [19], [20], [21], [22], [23] and self-triggered sampling schemes [24], [25] for NCSs. In the event-triggered sampling scheme, the state of the system is periodically/continuously monitored and new measured-data is picked up when a predetermined triggering condition is violated. In the self-triggered scheme, the state of the system does not need to be sampled except that the predicted value of a function related with the state is larger than a certain threshold. Thus, the communication burden is reduced compared with a traditional periodic time-triggered communication scheme [12]. However, an aperiodic sampling scheme usually depends on a specialized hardware to carry out high-rate sampling [19], [25], [26]. Especially, in wireless NCSs, the main cause for energy consumption is the idle listening for message, and the event-triggered sampling does not contribute to reduction of the time of the idle listening, since the sensor nodes are enforced to keep radio on to wait for reception of the sampled data [12]. To improve the energy efficiency for energy-constrained NCSs, a self-triggered sampling scheme (STS) is more appealing in comparison with eventtriggered sampling. A self-triggered control scheme presented in [24] is extended from real-time control systems to NCSs. For example, in [12], a new approach is proposed to control several processes over a shared wireless network by an STS. In [27], a self-triggered coordination is proposed for optimal deployment of robotic networks. Furthermore, in [28], a welldesigned sampling control is provided to enlarge the sampling intervals compared with the periodic sampling case.

Different from point-to-point connected traditional control systems, NCSs are of some non-ideal network quality of service (QoS), for example, data losses and communication delays due to the introduction of the communication networks. This non-ideal QoS may deteriorate the control effect of NCSs and even may destabilize the systems if not considering it in the analysis and design of NCSs [1], [3], [16]. There are some time-triggered sampling results in the literature for NCSs with data losses and communication delays [18], [29]. However, there are limited results on an aperiodic sampling scheme for NCSs by considering the above two issues simultaneously. In the limited results, an event-triggered communication scheme is presented for a distributed NCS with data losses and communication delays [10]. By use of the time-delay analysis approach, a discrete event-triggered sampling scheme is presented for NCSs by considering the communication delays and ignoring the data losses in the communications [30]. With a predetermined controller, an immature STS is proposed in [31] for an NCS, in which the estimation of the upper bound of event-triggered condition ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) in Lemma 1 and the self-triggered conditions ( 10)-( 12) in Theorem 2 are needed to be essentially improved to accord with the practical network conditions. Furthermore, how to co-design the networked controller and the communication scheme is not considered in [31]. These above mentioned issues greatly motivate the present research.

In this paper, a novel STS is proposed for an NCS with data losses and communication delays. The next predicted sampling instant will be estimated with respect to the data losses and communication delays; the latest successfully transmitted time-stamped packets and the desired H ∞ performance. In comparison with some existing time-triggered sampling schemes [18], [29], the proposed scheme has an advantage in reduction the communication burden. In comparison with some existing self-triggered sampling schemes [12], [31], how to co-design the sampling scheme and the controller has been discussed. Notice that in the existing event-triggered sampling schemes [10], [19], [30], the preselected eventtriggered condition must be checked at every sampling instant to decide whether the current sampling data should be transmitted or not over a communication-constrained wireless network. However, the proposed scheme in this paper can dynamically adjust the sampling interval without depending on the continuous/discrete measurement and on-line estimation of an event-triggered condition.

Notation: N denotes the set of positive integers. R n stands for the n-dimensional Euclidean space. R m×n denotes the set of all m × n real matrices. I is an identity matrix with an appropriate dimension. For symmetric matrices M and N , the notation M > N means that matrix M -N is positive definite.
• denotes the induced matrix 2-norm or the Euclidean vector norm as appropriate. z(t) L2 ∞ 0 z(t) 2 dt, L 2 denotes the linear space of all measurable functions with bounded • L2 .

div.head: II. THE DESCRIPTION OF AN NCS
div.p: Consider the system described by
div.formula: ẋ(t) = Ax(t) + Bu(t) + B 1 ω(t) z(t) = Cx(t) + Du(t)(1)
div.p: where u(t) ∈ R m , x(t) ∈ R n , and z(t) ∈ R p are the vectors of the control input, the system state, and the system output, respectively; A, B, C, D and B 1 are matrices of the appropriate dimensions; ω(t) ∈ R q is the disturbance in an L 2 space. In this paper, x(t 0 ) = x 0 is the given initial condition of the system (1), the sensor and the controller is connected by a wireless network.
For ease of exposition, the following notations are introduced:

• b k : the instant when the sampler obtains the measured data from the controlled plant ensured by an STS; • i k : the instant when the the measured data is successfully transmitted with a time-stamp; • p k : the predicted instant determined by a well-designed predictive agent while guaranteeing the desired performance; • f k : the instant when the sampled-data arrives at the actuator; • τ i k : the communication delay, which is the time interval from the i k to the f k when the time-stamped measureddata arrives at the actuator.
Let
div.formula: H k = b k+1 -b k .
div.p: Then, H k can be seen as a timevarying sampling period. Moreover, one can introduce that if {i k } ∞ k=0 = {b k } ∞ k=0 , this implies that there is no data loss in the communication; if {i k } ∞ k=0 ⊂ {b k } ∞ k=0 , this implies that there are data losses in the communication.

In this paper, it is assumed that the communication delay τ i k is time-varying and has the lower bound τ m and the upper bound τ M , which means that 0 < τ m ≤ τ i k ≤ τ M . It is also assumed that when the time stamped sampled-data arrives at the actuator, there is an acknowledge to be sent to the sensor simultaneously. The diagram of an NCS with an STS is depicted in Fig. 1, where

div.head: Controller
div.p: • the dashed line implies that the event of the sampleddata arrived at the actuator triggers the agent to predict the next sampling instant; • the sensor is driven by a self-triggered sampling method; the controller and the actuator are driven by an external event;

• the self-triggered sensor has the role to predict the next b k+1 , which is determined by the computed p k+1 by the predictive agent without considering the data losses and communication delays, and the practical sampling considering the allowable number of data losses d M and maximum communication delay τ M ; and • the zero-order-holder (ZOH) is used to store the latest arrived packet. The following state feedback control is used in this paper
where u(t + ) = lim t→t+0 u( t), K is the predetermined gain of the state feedback controller. Since the ZOH is used to store the latest arrived packet, it is clear that
div.formula: u(t), t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ) is a piecewise function.
div.p: From ( 1) and ( 25), the following closed-loop system is obtained
div.formula: ẋ(t) = Ax(t) + BKx(i k ) + B 1 ω(t) z(t) = Cx(t) + DKx(i k ), t ∈ [f k , f k+1 )(3)
div.p: The purpose of this paper is to provide a well-designed STS for an NCS by taking data losses and communication delays into consideration, such that the studied system (3) is asymptotically stable with an H ∞ norm bound γ, i.e., a) the system (3) with ω(t) = 0 is asymptotically stable; b) with the zero initial condition, z(t) L2 < γ ω(t) L2 for any nonzero ω(t) ∈ L 2 [0, ∞) and a predetermined γ > 0.

div.head: III. A NOVEL SELF-TRIGGERED SAMPLING SCHEME
div.p: Four theorems and an STS algorithm are provided in this section. In Subsection III-A, Theorem 1 is proposed to provide an event-triggered condition while preserving the desired control performance of the system (3). Theorem 2 is presented to evaluate the upper bound of the event-triggered condition in Theorem 1. In Subsection III-B, under consideration of the data loss and communication delay simultaneously, a novel STS is developed based on Theorems 1 and 2 to avoid real-time measurement and computation while reducing the utilization of limited network resources. Theorem 3 is provided to show that the desired performance is kept with the developed STS, and Theorem 4 is used to extend of Theorem 1 to tackle the controller design problem.

div.head: A. An upper bound estimation of an error dependent item
div.p: Define ρ(t) x(t)x(i k ), t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ) as a state error at the current sampling state x(t) and the latest successfully transmitted state x(i k ). Similar to [31], we now establish the following event-triggering criterion for the system (3).
Theorem 1: For given scalar γ > 0 and state feedback gain matrix K, if there are matrices W > 0, M > 0, S > 0, P > 0, Q > 0, and N > 0 of the appropriate dimensions such that
div.formula: i) for t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ), ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) ≤ x T (i k )Ψ 2 x(i k ),(4)
div.p: where
div.formula: Ψ 1 = N +M -W +S > 0 and Ψ 2 = W -K T D T DK- W N -1 W > 0; ii) Ω P B 1 B T 1 P γ 2 I > 0 (5)   Q -W C T DK P BK K T D T C S 0 K T B T P 0 M   > 0(6)
div.p: where
div.formula: Ω = -C T DK -K T D T C -P (A + BK) -(A + BK) T P -C T C -Q, then the closed-loop system (3) is asymptotically stable with an H ∞ norm bound γ.
div.p: Proof : Choose a Lyapunov functional V (x(t)) = x T (t)P x(t), where P > 0. Along the trajectory of (3), taking the derivative of V (x(t)) with regard to t yields
div.formula: V (x(t)) = x T (t)Πx(t) -2x T (t)P BKρ(t) + 2x T (t)P B 1 ω(t) -2x T (t)C T DKρ(t) + x T (i k )K T D T DKx(i k ) -z T (t)z(t)(7)
div.p: where
div.formula: Π = P (A + BK) + (A + BK) T P + C T C + B + C T DK + K T D T C.
div.p: To deal with the cross items in (7), it is noted that there exist a scalar γ >0, and matrices M >0 and S >0 such that     
div.formula: x T P x(t) + ρ T (t)M ρ(t) ≥ -2x T (t)P BKρ(t) x T Cx(t) + ρ T (t)Sρ(t) ≥ -2x T (t)C T DKρ(t) x T Bx(t) + γ 2 ω T (t)ω(t) ≥ 2x T (t)P B 1 ω(t)(8)
div.p: where P = P BKM -1 K T B T P , B = γ -2 P B 1 B T 1 P , and C = C T DKS -1 K T D T C. Then, by using Schur complement with ( 5) and ( 6), one can obtain
Combining ( 7)-( 9) together, we have
div.formula: V (x(t)) <ρ T (t)(M + S)ρ(t) -x T (t)W x(t) -z T (t)z(t) + γ 2 ω T (t)ω(t) + x T (i k )K T D T DKx(i k ) (10)
div.p: From ( 4) with N > 0, one can obtain
div.formula: M ≤(x(i k ) + ρ(t)) T W (x(i k ) + ρ(t)) -x T (i k )K T D T DKx(i k ) -2x T (i k )W ρ(t) -ρ T (t)N ρ(t) -x T (i k )W N -1 W x(i k ) ≤x T (t)W x(t) -x T (i k )K T D T DKx(i k )(11)
div.p: where M =ρ T (t)(M + S)ρ(t). From ( 10) and ( 11), we have that
div.formula: V (x(t)) < γ 2 ω T (t)ω(t) -z T (t)z(t)(12)
div.p: Integrating both sides of (12) from f k to t, t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ) and letting k → ∞, we derive that z(t) L2 < γ ω(t) L2 under zero initial condition. Moreover, when ω(t) = 0, from ( 4) and (10), we have that V (x(t)) < -λ x(t) 2 for a sufficiently small λ > 0. Then, we can conclude that the studied system (3) with ω(t) = 0 is asymptotically stable. This completes the proof.

Remark 1: Based on ( 5)-( 6), one can obtain M , S, W and N off-line based on the Matlab/LMI toolbox. Then, if ρ(t) in (4) can be real-time computed, and the number of successive data losses satisfies a prescribed condition, an event-triggered sampling scheme, such as the one proposed in [32] can be potentially used to determine the next sampling instant. However, since the above mentioned event-triggered sampling schemes are dependent on specialized hardware for the measurement [25], [26], [33], it is infeasible to directly use the event-triggered condition given in (4) to trigger the sampling in most general devices.

To improve the energy efficiency for the system (1) controlled over a wireless network, and inspired by a self-triggered control method used in a real-time system [24], [26], in the following, we present a novel STS to estimate the next sampling instant. The following theorem is critical to estimate the upper bound of event-triggered item ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) in (4).
Theorem 2: Consider the system (3). For t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ), the following inequality holds
div.formula: ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) ≤ λ 0 (t, f k , ω(t), x(i k ))(13)
div.p: where Ψ 1 is given in Theorem 1, and
div.formula: λ 0 (t, f k , ω(t), x(i k )) = 2λ 1 (t, f k , ω(t)) + 2λ T 2 (t, f k , x(i k ))λ 2 (t, f k , x(i k )) with λ 1 (t, f k , ω(t)) = (t -f k ) t f k ̥ 0 2 ω T (s)ω(s)ds λ 2 (t, f k , x(i k )) = t f k e ̥2(s-f k ) ds̥ 1 + e ̥2(t-f k ) Ψ 1 2 1 ρ(f k )
div.p: where
Proof : Based on the system (3), we estimate the upper bound of event-triggered item ρ
div.formula: T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) for t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ). Let Φ = {t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ) : ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) = 0}. The time derivative of Ψ 1 2 1 ρ(t) for t ∈ [f k , f k+1 )\Φ satisfies d dt Ψ 1 2 1 ρ(t) = Ψ 1 2 1 (A(ρ(t) + x(i k )) + BKx(i k ) + B 1 ω(t)) = ̥ 1 + ̥ 2 Ψ 1 2 1 ρ(t) + Ψ 1 2 1 B 1 ω(t)(15)
div.p: where the right hand side derivative is used when t = f k and ̥ 1 and ̥ 2 are defined in (14).
From (15) with the measured initial condition Ψ 1 ρ(f k ), we have that
div.formula: Ψ 1 2 1 ρ(t) = t f k e ̥2(s-f k ) ds̥ 1 + e ̥2(t-f k ) Ψ 1 2 1 ρ(f k ) λ2(t,f k ,x(i k )) + t f k e ̥2(t-s) Ψ 1 2 1 B 1 ω(s)ds λ3(t,f k ,ω(t))(16)
div.p: For simplicity, λ 2 (t, f k , ω(t)) and λ 3 (t, f k , x(i k )) in ( 2) are abbreviated as λ 2 and λ 3 . Then from (2), with the condition (λ 3λ 2 ) T (λ 3λ 2 ) ≥ 0, we have that
Using Jessen's inequality, for t
div.formula: ∈ [f k , f k+1 ), it is clear that λ T 3 λ 3 = t f k ω T (s)̥ T 0 ds t f k ̥ 0 ω(s)ds ≤(t -f k ) t f k ω T (s)̥ T 0 ̥ 0 ω(s)ds ≤ (t -f k ) t f k ̥ 0 2 ω T (s)ω(s)ds λ1(t,f k ,ω(t))(18)
div.p: Then, from ( 17) and ( 18), we arrive at (13). This completes the proof. Remark 2: In ( 13), the value of x(i k ) is known a priori due to the fact that x(i k ) is the latest successfully transmitted sampling value with the time-stamped i k labeled by the sensor. Therefore, the case of data losses in the communication has been considered in the utilization of Theorem 2. Furthermore, it is difficult to directly calculate λ 1 (t, f k , ω(t)) since an unknown disturbance ω(t) is included in (13). However, since ω(t) belongs to an L 2 space, to make it solvable, in the following subsection we will set ω(t) L2 to its upper bound.

Remark 3: Theorem 2 has a key role in the estimation of the upper bound of ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) in Theorem 1 in order to derive an STS. Notice that that a similar estimation of the upper bound of event-triggered item ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) is given in Lemma 1 in [31]. Unfortunately, Lemma 1 in [31] is incorrect due to incorrect differential equations. Therefore, the corresponding results derived in [31] are incorrect.

div.head: B. A self-triggered sampling scheme
div.p: Notice that Theorem 1 cannot be directly used to determine the next sampling instant if the value of ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) in Eq.( 4) can not be on-line measured and calculated. To tackle above problem, in this subsection, we will develop a novel STS to guarantee the asymptotic stability of the system (3) with the H ∞ norm bound γ by taking data losses and communication delays into account simultaneously.
The STS algorithm is developed with a diagram depicted in Fig. 2.

div.head: Algorithm 1: Obtaining the sampling instant b k+1
div.p: Step 1. Given τ m , ω, τ M , d M and L, where ω denotes the upper bound of the disturbance ω(t), τ M is the upper bound of the communication delay τ i k , d M is the allowable maximum number of consecutive data losses, and L denotes and the prescribed allowable maximum sampling interval between two consecutive samplings; Step 2. At f k , the self-triggered sensor begins to predict the next proximately violated instant p k+1 , which is the
div.formula: λ 0 (t, f k , ω, x(i k ) ≤ x T (i k )Ψ 2 x(i k )(19)
div.p: In the case of p k+1 > L+f k , one sets
div.formula: p k+1 = L+f k ; Step 3. The next estimated instant b k+1 is set as b k+1 = p k+1 -d M τ M ; Step 4. If b k+1 + τ m < f k , one sets b k+1 = f k .
div.p: From Algorithm 1, one can conclude that the proposed STS is feasible and can tolerate certain extent of data losses and communication delays. For instance, Step 4 is used to to deal with an unreasonable case in the self-triggered sampling. From Fig. 3, it is seen that b k+1 < f k , where the estimated sampling instant p k+1 is determined by (19), and the calculated next sampling instant b k+1 is computed based on Step 3. This implies that b k+1 should be carried out before f k . In other words, the sequence of next sampling instant f k and estimated sampling instant b k+1 is out of order. Thus, this initial predicted b k+1 is replaced by f k at Step 4.
From the above description, one can see that the proposed STS can be implemented in practice by taking data losses and communication delays into account.

Remark 4: Notice that the above mentioned STS includes cases of no data loss and constant communication delay in the communications as its special cases. For example, when there is no data loss in the communications, which means that d M = 0, one can derive that b k+1 = p k+1 in Step 3. In this case the proposed STS is still eligible.
Remark 5: If Step 4 is not included in Algorithm 1, it is possible that the next estimated instant b k+1 + τ m arriving at the actuator is less than the instant f k , that is,
div.formula: f k > b k+1 +τ m .
div.p: Clearly, it is not reasonable and should be avoided. Therefore,
Step 3

div.head: Sensor Actuator
div.p: Step 2
Step 4 Fig. 3. An example with an invalid sampling instant b k+1
Step 4 plays an important role in ensuring the feasibility of the predicted sampling instant.
Remark 6: From Step 2 to Step 4, it is derived that the least estimated sampling instant b k+1 is f k . Then, the least sampling interval can be calculated as
div.formula: min k H k = min k (b k+1 -b k ) = min k (i k + τ i k -b k )(20)
div.p: From the definitions i k and b k , we can derive that b k ≤ i k .
Then from (20), we have min k H k = τ m . Since τ m is strictly larger than zero, on can conclude that H k > 0. This is important since there is no Zeno behavior [9] in the proposed scheme.

Remark 7: Notice that the the computation complexity of Algorithm 1 is dependent on the number of decision variables N and matrix rows L in ( 5)-( 6), and the searching step increment ζ to find the adaptive t in Step 2. The computation complexity of Algorithm 1 can be estimated as being proportional to N 3 Lζ -1 [34]. Since N = 3n 2 + 3n and L = 5n, where n is the given dimension of state variables in ( 5)-( 6), the searching precision and the computational complexity are related to ζ directly. Smaller ζ, more computations are required [32].
From Algorithm 1, it is derived that the maximum allowable number of consecutive data losses is d M . Furthermore, from ( 13) and ( 19), we have
div.formula: ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) ≤ x T (i k )Ψ 2 x(i k )(21)
div.p: Then, by Theorems 1 and 2 and under the self-triggered sampling Algorithm 1, for the system (3), we have the following theorem for guaranteeing the asymptotic stability with an H ∞ norm bound γ. Theorem 3: For given scalar γ > 0 and state feedback gain matrix K, under the STS Algorithm 1, if there are matrices M > 0, W > 0, Q > 0, S > 0, P > 0 and N > 0 of the appropriate dimensions such that ( 5), ( 6) and ( 19) hold for t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ), then the system (3) is asymptotically stable with an allowable maximum number of consecutive data losses d M and an H ∞ norm bound γ.

The role of Theorem 2 is to estimate the upper bound of event-triggered item ρ T (t)Ψ 1 ρ(t) in (4) of Theorem 1. Then, this estimated value is used in Theorem 2 to compare with the value of x T (i k )Ψ 2 x(i k ) in (19) to decide whether the current measured-data should to be transmitted or not. Therefore, different from Theorem 1, Theorem 2 does not depend on some specialized hardware for continuous measurement of the value of ρ(t). Moreover, notice that sufficient conditions ( 6) and ( 19) are derived in Theorems 1 and 2, and the allowable maximum number of consecutive data losses are considered in Algorithm 1, how to get fewer conservative criteria and algorithm are needed to be further study in the future.
As an extension of this work, define
div.formula: X = P -1 , M = XM X, S = XSX, W = XW X, Q = XQX, Ñ = XN X and Y = KX.
div.p: Then, pre-and post-multiplying both sides of ( 5) and ( 6) with diag(X, I) and diag(X, X, X), respectively, and using Schur complement, one can readily derive the following Theorem based on Theorem 1.

Theorem 4: For a given scalar γ > 0, the system (3) is asymptotically stable with an H ∞ norm bound γ and K = Y X -1 , if there exist matrices X > 0, M > 0, S > 0, W > 0, Q > 0 and Ñ > 0 of the appropriate dimensions such that the conditions ( 22) and (23)
div.formula: hold for t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ). i) for t ∈ [f k , f k+1 ), ρ T (t) Ψ1 ρ(t) ≤ x T (i k ) Ψ2 x(i k ),(22)
div.p: where
div.formula: Ψ1 = X -1 M X -1 + X -1 SX -1 -X -1 W X -1 + X -1 Ñ X -1 > 0 and Ψ2 = X -1 W X -1 - X -1 W Ñ -1 W X -1 -X -1 Y T D T DY X -1 > 0; ii)     Ω B 1 √ 2XC T Y T D T B T 1 γ 2 I 0 0 √ 2CX 0 I 0 DY 0 0 I     > 0(23)
  Q -W BY C T DY Y T B T M 0 Y T D T C 0 S   > 0(24)
div.p: where
div.formula: Ω = -(AX + BY ) -(XA + BY ) T -Q. Remark 8:
div.p: If the controller gain is not pre-given, based on Theorem 4, one can co-design the controller gain and the parameters of the communication scheme for the system (3). For example, one can design the different controller gains based on (23) and (24), then use the communication scheme with the different controller and communication parameters under the test or simulation plat to find the desired parameters. Similar algorithm can be found in [32], due to limitation of page, it is omitted in this paper.

Remark 9: From the system (1), one can see clearly that the system includes the external disturbance as its component. In general, the system (1) cannot be discretized due to the fact that there exists the unknown external disturbance in the system. In the case of ω(t) = 0, the system (1) reduces to the following system
div.formula: ẋ(t) = Ax(t) + Bu(t) z(t) = Cx(t) + Du(t)(25)
div.p: In this situation, one can first discretize the system (25) to obtain an discrete equivalent of the system. Then, designing a controller for the discretized system by taking into account the delays and the constant control action between arriving samples of the control action may lead to the similar performance to the one obtained with the approach in this paper.

div.head: IV. EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, an inverted pendulum and a one-area power system controlled over IEEE 802.15.4-based wireless networks are used to illustrate the effectiveness of proposed sampling scheme.
Example 1: The state equation of an inverted pendulum is given as [29], [35]

Set γ = 200 and L = 0.36sec. First, we consider two cases: the constant communication delay τ i k = 0.09sec, and the time-varying communication delay on an interval, τ i k ∈ [0.03sec, 0.09sec]. With the different number of successive data losses, that is, d M = 1, 3, the used sampling instants and the predicted sampling instants based on Algorithm 1 are shown in Figures 4567, where '⋄' is the practically used sampling instant, and '+' is the estimated sampling instant. One can see that from Figure 4 to Figure 7: i) Most samplings occur at the initial adjustment period, and the sampling interval has lower and upper bounds;

ii) When the system states trend to the operating point, the proposed sampling scheme has the larger average sampling period while preserving the desired control performance; and iii) When the number of successive data losses increases, the allowable sampling intervals decrease. This shows that the proposed STS can adaptively adjust the sampling interval based on the allowable number of successive data losses. From (20), one can readily derive that the sampling interval should vary between 0.12sec and 0.36sec in Figures 4 and5, and between 0.06sec and 0.36sec in Figures 6 and7. However, it can be seen that there are some special instants, such as those in 0-5 seconds, are lower than 0.12sec. As stated in Remark 6, the allowable lower bound of the sampling period is adopted in this special case. In addition, with the given initial condition x(0) = [2, -1] T , the system state responses are depicted in Fig. 8.

For the purpose of comparison, for a simulation time Example 2: The load frequency control (LFC) of a onearea power system over a wireless network is depicted in Fig. 9, where ∆f , ∆P v , ∆P m and ∆P d denote the deviation of frequency, valve position, the generator output and power system load. M , R, D, T g and T ch denote the moment of inertia, speed drop, the generator damping coefficient, the time constant of the governor and the time constant of the turbine, respectively. Given the initial values of the parameters T ch = 0.3, T g = 0.1, R = 0.05, D = 1.0, β = 21.0, M = 10. By using a PI controller u(t) = -K P ACE -K I ACE, where ACE is the input of LFC, K p and K I are the pregiven proportional and integral gains, the dynamic model of the closed-loop power system with the LFC can be expressed as (3) with 11 with constant and time-varying delays respectively, where '⋄' is the practically used sampling instant, and '+' is the estimated sampling instant. In the case of T = 20sec, one can get the number of transmitted packets is 251 with the proposed sampling scheme, in comparison with the time-triggered sampling adopted in [36], only 25.1% measured packets need to be transmitted over a wireless network. The corresponding state responses of system (3) is shown in Figures 10 and11. For further comparison, Table II lists the number of the sampled packets for different sampling schemes. One can see that the number of sampled-data in the proposed STS is smaller than that in the traditional TTS. V. CONCLUSION A novel STS has been proposed for a wireless NCS by considering the data losses and communication delays simultaneously. This scheme has an important role in reducing the utilization of the limited communication resources and energy while preserving the desired performance for the system under consideration. Based on the error estimation technique, the state value of the next sampling instant has been estimated without depending on on-line calculation of the event-triggered condition. Furthermore, the proposed STS can well adjust the sampling period with respect to the allowable number of consecutive data losses and the communication delays. Two examples on control of an inverted pendulum and LFC of a one-area power system have been given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed STS. The network-based performance tracking control of complex industrial processes with STS will be considered in the future research.
